questions.text: A 11-year-old is having grey patch tinea capitis. The most appropriate line of therapy is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral griseofulvin Tinea capitis is treated with oral griseofulvin.

Treatment Microsporum species (grey patch and some types of kerion) Trichophyton species (e.g. black dot, favus and some types of kerion) Oral griseofulvin is the DOC Oral terbinafine is the DOC

questions.text: You are sitting in a dermatology OPD where you see a patient with a flaky and itchy lesion on his hair. The resident doctor took out the instrument as shown in the picture below to examine the lesions. All are true about the instrument shown below and examination except:

options.label: B
options.text: Show faint yellow colour on lesions of Erythrasma

options.label: D
options.text: The filter consists of barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide

questions.correct_answer: B. Show faint yellow colour on lesions of Erythrasma
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Show faint yellow colour on lesions of Erythrasma The image is of a wood lamp It shows a Coral pink colour on lesions of Erythrasma . Wood’s lamp It is used as a diagnostic test . It consists of a wood filter containing barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide . Emits black light which is not visible to the naked eye at a wavelength of 320-450 nm and is used to examine the skin and hair. The lamp can be used to detect subclinical infections and also used to assess the response of treatment. The most frequent causes of false results include the bluish or purplish fluorescence generated by scales, serum, exudates, and ointments containing petrolatum, as well as an inadequately darkened environment, light reflected from the examiner's clothing. It is important to remember that infections with Trichophyton species (except schoenleinni ) and some infections with M. audouinii , M. canis do not show fluorescence.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Rest all other options are true.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came to the dermatology OPD with complaints of an itchy rash on her neck. Your senior suspects a fungal infection and asked you to collect the skin scraping and send it for direct examination. Which among the following is true for the Potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount examination?

options.label: A
options.text: More time-consuming than phase contrast and dark field microscopy

options.label: B
options.text: 10 to 30% potassium hydroxide is used in routine examinations.

options.label: C
options.text: Aspergillus shows spaghetti and meatball appearance on the KOH mount

options.label: D
options.text: Boiling of the skin and nail scraping is done to speed up the process

questions.correct_answer: B. 10 to 30% potassium hydroxide is used in routine examinations.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10 to 30% potassium hydroxide is used in routine examinations. Potassium hydroxide preparation is one of the most commonly used direct fungal stains. Specimens are usually mounted in 10–30% potassium hydroxide ; the higher the percentage, the faster the specimen will clear. Treatment of skin scrapings, nails, or hairs with potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount dissolves tissue material while leaving the alkali-resistant fungi intact and aids in diagnosing mycoses.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- The time required for clearing using KOH is usually 5 minutes making it a rapid detection method of fungal elements. On the other hand, Phase‐contrast and darkfield microscopy require that the specimen be really thin, and thus may need a longer period of softening of the material than the bright field. Option C- Malassezia furfur shows Spaghetti and meatball appearance on KOH mount. Option D- Boiling should be avoided because it leads to the formation of artefacts. For skin scrapings and nails, warming is done gently over the pilot light of a Bunsen burner to speed up the process.

questions.text: Which species does not cause tinea capitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epidermophyton floccosum Epidermophyton floccosum does not involve hairs. Tinea capitis is mainly caused by microsporum and trichophyton species

Highyeild:

Areas of involvements in dermatophytes Site Trichophyton Epidermophyton Microsporum Epidermis Yes No Yes Hair Yes Yes Yes Nail Yes Yes No

Extraedge:

Tinea capitis Disease of children. Rare in adults Patchy alopecia occurs Either inflames the scalp (inflammatory T. capitis) or does not inflame (non-inflammatory T. capitis) All MCQs on T. capitis will have a child in the question Pick up phrase in the MCQ—“Easy pluckability of hair”, “broken hairs

questions.text: You are posted in a health camp where you see a male patient with pink-brown, scaly lesions present over his chest, back and upper arms as shown in the picture. You took the skin scrapings and sent them for microscopic examination. On application of periodic acid-Schiff reagent, the microscopic view is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pityriasis versicolor The given clinical scenario of light brown–pink, scaly macules with distribution over the trunk is of Pityriasis Versicolor caused by infection with the yeast-like fungus Malassezia furfur (Pityrosporon ovale). More common in hot and humid weather, although it can occur at any time of the year. Clusters of budding yeast-like cells and short and occasionally branching hyphae are described as the ‘spaghetti and meatball’ Spores = Meatballs and Pseudohyphae = spaghetti. Treatment - Selenium sulfide and topical antifungal

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Tinea corporis, Seborrhoeic dermatitis, pityriasis rosea, secondary syphilis and piñata show more inflammatory changes and do not produce fine scales like Pityriasis Versicolor. Option B: Erythrasma may closely mimic pityriasis versicolor with pigmentary change and scaling, but satellite lesions are less common, and pink fluorescence under the Wood’s lamp is often present. Option C: Vitiligo, is a skin condition that causes loss of pigmentation, resulting in white patches on the skin. It occurs when the melanocytes, which produce pigment in the skin, are destroyed

Extraedge:

Pityriasis can produce both hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation. It produces hypopigmentation due to the degradation of lipids which produces acids that inhibit the tyrosinase enzyme involved in melanin synthesis. Hyperpigmentation can also occur due to an inflammatory response.

questions.text: Skin scraping from hypopigmented, red-brown, slightly scaly lesions on the back of a 25 years old male, in potassium hydroxide (KOH) and Calcofluor white UV illumination is shown below. Which of the following is true about the disease?

options.label: B
options.text: It is caused by a dermatophyte

options.label: C
options.text: The first line treatment is anti-bacterial with steroid

options.label: D
options.text: The appearance is described as a ' crushed ping pong ball' appearance

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Relapse is very common. The given image shows the Spaghetti and Meatball appearance characteristic of cutaneous mycoses - Tinea Versicolor or Pityriasis Versicolor. The causative organism of Pityriasis Versicolor is Malassezia species ( globosa , M.furfur and M.sympodialis ) Relapse is very common irrespective of the primary treatment.

Highyeild:

Treatment ladder:- First line Topical azoles twice daily for 2-3 weeks Terbinafine 1% cream twice daily for 2-3 weeks Ketoconazole shampoo twice weekly for 2-3 weeks 5% selenium shampoo alternative days for 2-3 weeks Second line Itraconazole 200 mg daily for 5 days

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option. B, C & D are described for Pneumocystis Carinii with silver stain.

questions.text: A 36-year-factory worker developed itchy annular scaly plaques in groin. Application of steroid ointment gives temporary relief but the plaques continued to grow at periphery. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tinea incognito Tinea Incognito (“Incognito” = No cognition, i.e. not be able to diagnose easily) is a term applied to atypical clinical lesions of tinea, usually produced by incorrect treatment with a topical corticosteroid. Since steroids suppress inflammation without treatment of fungus, the lesions may be asymptomatic and extensive, and may even lack scaling. The diagnosis may be established by KOH examination or biopsy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Erythema chronicum migrans is the lesion of tick-borne spirochetosis, Lyme disease. "Bull's eye" pattern lesions/ target lesions are seen at bite site and is often accompanied by symptoms of a viral-like illness, including fatigue, headache, body aches, fever, and chills. Option C- Granuloma annulare is a granulomatous disease presents as erythematous lesions arranged in an annular configuration (hence the name granuloma annulare) on the upper extremities. Disease has been associated with diabetes mellitus Option D- Psoriasis does not present as annular scaly groin lesions

questions.text: An athlete comes with itchy, scaly lesions on one foot as shown in the image below. He also has nail discoloration. What is false regarding the condition shown below?

options.label: C
options.text: Griseofulvin is the drug of choice

questions.correct_answer: C. Griseofulvin is the drug of choice
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Griseofulvin is the drug of choice The diagnosis here is tinea pedis (athlete foot). It is commonly caused by T. rubrum species. Itchy scaling here points to the diagnosis. Nail discoloration is s/o onychomycosis Griseofulvin is the drug of choice in tinea capitis, not tinea pedis. For tinea pedis, better would be to give either itraconazole or terbinafine.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Athlete’s due to the moisture on feet suffer from more T.pedis. Hence, also called athlete’s foot Option B- Mainly, Trichophyton rubrum causes tinea pedis. Trichophyton interdigitale and Epidermophyton floccosum are also involved. Option D - Interdigital scaling is very common along with plantar surface involvement

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was brought to the OPD by his mother with a complaint of grey patchy lesions over the scalp as shown in the image below. On further examination, you see grey, circular patches with partial alopecia which show green fluorescence under wood's light. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ectothrix The given clinical picture is suggestive of Ectothrix infection . It is characterized by grey, fine scaling with sharp circular margins. The scaling is adherent to hair but the shaft doesn't normally break with minimal inflammation. It is more commonly seen in children than adults and shows green fluorescence underwood light. Infection with ferrugineum may produce non-fluorescent cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Kerion - These are inflamed, indurated, tender, boggy swelling with hair, vesicles and pustules Option C- Seborrhoeic dermatitis- Usually more diffuse than Tinea capitis Option D- Endothrix - Brittle hair shaft which breaks at the level of the scalp giving it a Black dot appearance.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b 1. Grey patch | c. Scaly patch 2. Black dot | d. Fractured hairs with broken hairs 3. Kerion | a. Boggy swelling 4. Favus | b. Scutulum Tinea capitis describes dermatophyte infection of hair and scalp, typically caused by Trichophyton and Microsporum species in children. The most common cause worldwide is Microsporum canis. Tinea capitis can be classified according to the inflammatory component of clinical presentation namely inflammatory (kerion and favus) and noninflammatory (gray patch and black dot types) or according to the size and the location of the spore, ectothrix (spores outside the hair shaft), and endothrix (spores inside the hair shaft).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with painful boggy swelling of scalp, multiple sinuses with purulent discharge, easily pluckable hair and enlarged lymph nodes in occipital region. Which one of the following would be most helpful for diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

KOH mount Clinically, kerion presents as painful, inflammatory boggy swelling, with pus and sinus formation. Easily pluckable hair is a sign of T. capitis and enlarged lymph nodes in occipital region suggests inflammation on scalp. The organisms for kerion are Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Trichophyton verrucosum and Microsporum canis. KOH mount would be done here.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Biopsy is not required as the diagnosis can be done with KOH mount Option C- The infection is fungal, not bacterial Option D- Patch test is done for allergic contact dermatitis

questions.text: A 41-year-old HIV-positive female came to the OPD with painful mouth lesions. There were greyish-white membranous plaques found on the surface of the tongue and buccal mucosa and maceration at the angle of the mouth. On the mucous membranes, the base of these plaques is moist, reddish, and macerated. Lab tests were done shown below. What is the possible cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Candidal oral thrush The given clinical scenario in an immunocompromised patient (HIV positive) presenting with greyish-white membranous plaques on the surface of the tongue is suggestive of Candidal oral thrush. Oral thrush A most common presentation of candida in the mouth. The base of the plaques is moist, reddish, and macerated A dry mouth predisposes to candidal growth because innate immunity molecules in the saliva inhibit candida. Perleche: When the infection extends onto the angles of the mouth. Predisposing factors: Common in elderly, immunocompromised (HIV) debilitated, malnourished and diabetic patients. The broad-spectrum antibiotic also predisposes to candidiasis.

Highyeild:

Candida: Yeast-like fungi which form Pseudohyphae and budding at 20°C Germ tube at 37°C aka Reynolds Braude Phenomenon Can produce both Systemic and Superficial fungal infections: Oral Candidiasis Esophageal candidiasis: AIDS-defining illness, shaggy esophagus Candida onychomycosis Vulvovaginitis: Associated with antibiotic use and diabetes Candidiasis balanoposthitis: Swelling of prepuce, radial fissuring Diaper rash Infective endocarditis: People who inject drugs Candidal intertrigo: skin folds Disseminated candidiasis: In neutropenia patients Treatment: Oral or topical azoles Nystatin Echinocandins and Amphotericin B for systemic diseases

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Leukoplakia: It is a white patch or plaque (cannot be rubbed off) that develops in the oral cavity with malignant potential and is strongly associated with tobacco use. Option B. Vitamin B2 deficiency: It causes cheilosis, magenta tongue and corneal neovascularization Option D. Herpetic glossitis: Rare form of oral HSV1 characterised by crater-like ulcers, diffuse erythema, pseudo-tumoral plaques or nodules.

questions.text: A mother brought her 10-month-old baby. With rashes on the buttock. The lady has been applying over-the-counter medication from the chemist but it has led to a further increase in lesions. She is worried about what to do. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nappy candidiasis The given clinical history of rash in the diaper area and use of over-the-counter drugs (most likely containing steroid preparations ) is suggestive of Diaper candidiasis or Nappy candidiasis. Steroid creams applied to this site not only modify the clinical features but are probably advantageous to Candida. Moreover, if the bacterial flora has been suppressed by a topical antibiotic, this will also favour yeast growth.

Highyeild:

Candida: Yeast-like fungi which form Pseudohyphae and budding at 20°C Germ tube at 37°C aka Reynolds Braude Phenomenon Can produce both Systemic and Superficial fungal infections: Oral Candidiasis Esophageal candidiasis: AIDS-defining illness, shaggy esophagus Candida onychomycosis Vulvovaginitis: Associated with antibiotic use and diabetes Candidiasis balanoposthitis: Swelling of the prepuce, radial fissuring Diaper rash Infective endocarditis: People who inject drugs Candidal intertrigo: skin folds Disseminated candidiasis: In neutropenia patients Treatment: Oral or topical azoles Nystatin Echinocandins and Amphotericin B for systemic diseases

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis: It is a common, chronic, or relapsing form of eczema/dermatitis that mainly affects the sebaceous gland-rich regions of the scalp, face, and trunk. It presents scaly hypopigmented macules and patches. Option B. Irritant dermatitis: It is a form of skin inflammation caused by contact with substances and/or environmental factors that injure the skin, damaging the skin barrier characterised by Localised well-defined, redness, papules, swelling, and Option D. questions.text: A patient from Himachal Pradesh gets a thorn prick and subsequently presents with a verrucous lesion as shown. Microscopy shows pigmented bodies. The diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chromoblastomycosis Chromoblastomycosis Chronic infection caused by pigmented fungi (Phialophora and Fonsecaea species) Inoculation of the organism through a thorn prick Clinical: Warty, cauliflower-like growth on the foot or lower leg (site of prick) Histology: A foreign‐body granuloma forms. Groups of fungal cells may be seen within giant cells. These fungal cells are golden brown in color (sclerotic, copper penny, medlar or muriform bodies).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Sporotrichosis is caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii, which as a saprophyte lives on grass and other plants (hence, occupations like florists, gardeners, farmers are prone when they get thorn pricks). Most common cutaneous presentation-“lymphatic type”- organism progresses along lymphatics to create a linear chain of ulcerating nodules and sinuses along these lymphatics. On histopathology, the fungus is seen in the tissue as small cigar‐shaped or oval yeasts, or be surrounded by a radiating, eosinophilic substance (called as asteroid bodies) Option C- Mycetoma is caused either by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma) or true fungi (eumycetoma), both being saprophytes in soil. It causes severe destruction of dermis, subcutaneous tissue and even underlying bone. Triad of mycetoma is swelling of foot, sinus and grains. Option D- Verruca presents as cauliflower masses like chromoblastomycosis but does not pigmented bodies on microscopy.

questions.text: A farmer from up came to the OPD with ulcerating nodules on the leg with pus discharge from the same. It is slowly progressing and worsening. On examination regional lymphadenopathy is seen. The doctor ordered HPE with the below finding. Diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sporotrichosis The HPE shows a classical asteroid bod y suggestive of Sporotrichosis Sporotrichosis: A Subcutaneous mycosis is aka rose gardener's disease Causative organism : Dimorphic fungi S .Schenckii Lives on vegetations Diagnosis: The fungus is present in the tissue, usually in the form of small (3–5 μm) cigar‐shaped or oval yeasts, and these may, on occasion, be surrounded by a thick, radiate, eosinophilic substance that forms the distinctive asteroid bodies. Culture- At 25°C yeast is converted to mould form- Rosette of conidiophores Treatment: Itraconazole, potassium iodide

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Fish tank granuloma: Presents as a slow-growing inflamed red bump at the trauma site caused by Mycobacterium marinum Option B. Leishmaniasis: Cutaneous Leishmania is caused by L.Tropica characteristically producing oriental sore. Option D. Sarcoidosis: Systemic inflammatory disease producing widespread non-caseating granulomas

questions.text: A 24-year-old male had multiple small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back for the last three months. The macules were circular, arranged around follicles and many had coalesced to form large sheets. The surface showed fine scaling. He had similar lesions one year ago which subsided with treatment. The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Potassium hydroxide mount The diagnosis is pityriasis versicolor. KOH mount is done to show ‘spaghetti and meat ball appearance’

Highyeild:

Pityriasis versicolor Caused by Malassezia yeasts. Confluent, scaly, variously colored lesions, mainly on oily areas which are also sweaty like the upper trunk –m/c site Scale is fine, powdery, and branny The usual presentation in Indian skin is hypopigmented macules and patches Scratch sign -Since scaling is minimal; it may be emphasized by firmly scratching the skin

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- SSS is done for leprosy (shows lepra bacilli on ZN stain) and PKDL (shows LD bodies on giemsa stain) Option C- Biopsy is not required for diagnosis Option D- Tzanck smear is done on blistering disorders mainly, like herpes (shows multinucleate giant cells) and pemphigus (shows unicellular acantholytic cells)

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer came with the complaint of a small warty lesion which is gradually progressing to flat plaque and the lesion is painless with associated itching. What is the treatment of the same?

options.label: D
options.text: Anti virals till the lesion subside

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Itraconazole 200 mg daily The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Chromoblastomycosis. Itraconazole is used for treatment of chromoblastomycosis. Chromoblastomycosis: Chronic fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues Cause : pigmented fungi, which produce thick‐walled single‐ or multi cell clusters ( sclerotic or muriform bodies) in tissue. Characteristics : slow‐growing exophytic lesions, usually on the feet and legs. Treatment: Antifungal chemotherapy, heat application Chromoblastomycosis: tissue section. The natural brown pigment of the fungal muniform cells is clearly visible. The cells divide by fission and may form septe in more than one plane of division (Courtesy of the Department of Medical Mycology, St John's Institute of Dermatology, King's College London, London, UK.)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Radical surgery: It is not recommended for the treatment of cutaneous warts because it can cause scarring and is usually not necessary. Option C. Dapsone with streptomycin: It is a treatment for leprosy, which is caused by a bacterium called Mycobacterium leprae. Option D. Antivirals: These are used to treat viral infections, and they are not effective against fungal infections like chromoblastomycosis.

questions.text: A 24 year old cave explorer presented with umbilicated papules and nodules with fever, cough and chest discomfort. The physician ordered some tests and the patient is found to be HIV positive and a diagnosis of a systemic mycosis is made. What is the cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Histoplasmosis The given clinical history of fever, and cough in a spelunker (Cave explorer) with palatal ulcer and splenomegaly is suggestive of Histoplasmosis. Histoplasmosis aka Darling's disease Cause: A fungal infection caused by H. capsulatum . Associated with bird and bat droppings (Caves) Characteristics: pulmonary involvement and cutaneous involvement. Pulmonary involvement: Cough, chest pain, dyspnea Cutaneous involvement : It is rare and is characterized by a nodule or indurated ulcer and there is often local lymphadenopathy. Diagnosis: Established by identifying the intracellular yeast cells of Histoplasma in sputum, peripheral blood, bone marrow or biopsy specimen. Treatment: Local infection: Oral itraconazole or fluconazole is the drug of choice Systemic infection: Amphotericin B

Highyeild:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Sporotrichosis: It is a fungal infection caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii, which usually causes a localized infection in the skin and lymph nodes, not a systemic infection. Option C. Candidiasis: It can cause systemic infections in immunocompromised patients and is not associated with palatal ulcers or splenomegaly. Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: It is a fungal infection caused by the fungus Coccidioides immitis, which typically causes respiratory symptoms such as cough and shortness of breath, but it is not usually associated with palatal ulcers or splenomegaly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a rash on his thigh for 10 days. He reports that the rash has been enlarging and is intensely itchy. Two weeks ago, he adopted a stray dog from an animal shelter. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the examination findings is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dermatophyte infection The given clinical scenario of skin infection with a history of contact with an animal (eg., this patient's recently adopted dog) is suggestive of fungal infection-Dermatophytosis.

Highyeild:

DERMATOPHYTE Affects Macroconidia Microconidia Trichophyton Skin, Hair, Nail Pencil shaped +++ Microsporum Skin, Hair Spindle-shaped ++ Epidermophyton Skin, Nails Club / boat-shaped - Spreads by coming in contact with an infected person or animals Diagnosis: Confirmed by obtaining scales from a lesion and visualizing branching, and septate hyphae on a KOH test. Treatment: Topical and systemic antifungals

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Psoriasis: A papulosquamous disorder with an erythematous plaque with silvery white scaling over the extensors. It shows Burkley membrane and on scratching there are pinpoint bleeding spots called Auspitz sign Option B. Erythrasma: Caused by Corynebacterium infection in patients with hyperhydrosis, leading to keratolysis and asymmetrical non-itchy rash in axilla most commonly. Option C. Scabies: Caused by Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis , presenting as nocturnal pruritus, burrows in the skin in stratum corneum present in a distribution called the circle of Hebra. There is also simultaneous infection of family members.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male factory worker comes to the physician complaining of an itchy rash on his buttock. Physical examination reveals an annular and scaling plaque with central clearing on the chest. KOH preparation of skin scrapings shows branching septate hyphae and topical application of terbinafine was prescribed. Which of the following mechanisms of action explains the antifungal activity of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibition of squalene epoxidase The patient described in this vignette is presenting with symptoms of tinea corporis. Presentation: Clinically tinea corporis presents as an annular scaling plaque with well-demarcated, raised erythematous borders and central clearing . Treatment: Terbinafine is a commonly used drug for the treatment of dermatophytosis. Class: Aallylamines and may be used topically or orally. MOA: Terbinafine inhibits lanosterol synthesis by inhibiting the enzyme squalene epoxidase. -This drug tends to accumulate in the skin and its appendages, and its side effects are mild by the topical route.

Highyeild:

Important antifungals mechanism of action: Class of drug Mechanism of action Examples Allyl amines Inhibits lanosterol synthesis by inhibiting squalene epoxidase Terbinafine Antimetabolite Inhibits nucleic acid synthesis Flucytosine Azoles Inhibits ergosterol synthesis by inhibiting 14-alpha-demethylase Ketoconazole Polyenes Disrupts cell membrane integrity Amphotericin B Griseofulvin Act on mitotic spindle

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Binding to ergosterol: It is the mechanism of action of polyene antifungal drugs like amphotericin B. Option C. Blocking p-D-glucan synthesis: It is the mechanism of action of echinocandin antifungal drugs like caspofungin. Option D. Preventing mitosis by binding tubulin: It is the mechanism of action of antifungal drugs like griseofulvin.

questions.text: A washerwoman presents with whitish discoloration of web spaces of toes. The dermatologist also sees a few satellite lesions. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Candidiasis The skin of toe webs exhibits white, macerated, and thickened epidermis. Its appearance is very similar to that of tinea pedis, but has satellite lesions in candidiasis. Moist working conditions like washerwomen or use of tight and closed shoes for prolonged periods of time may induce this condition

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Psoriasis will have red scaly lesions on extensors and not common in webs Option B- Tinea pedis usually has scaly lesions in webs. No satellite lesions. Option D- Eczema has scaly, oozing lesions. Web not a common site

Another cause of satellite lesion is borderline tuberculoid (BT) Hansen’s disease

questions.text: A 30 years old female presented with scarring alopecia almost involving the entire scalp and yellowish-crusted lesions over the vertex and occipital region. She revealed that these lesions started 5 years back and lead to scarring alopecia. Nails and mucous membrane appears normal. Skin biopsy showed numerous fungal hyphae. Which is the first line drug which acts on mitotic spindle used in treatment ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Griseofulvin The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an Inflammatory type of Tinea capitis, Favus . Griseofulvin is the first line of treatment which acts on mitotic spindle. Causative organism- Trichophyton schoenleinii Lesions: On the scalp active lesion demonstrates a concave sulfur-yellow crust called a "scutula " formed around loose wiry hairs Later they heal with thin smooth atrophic scarring. Each scutulum develops around a hair, which pierces it centrally . Adjacent crusts enlarge to become confluent and form a mass of yellow crusting. Extensive, patchy hair loss with cicatricial alopecia and atrophy among patches of normal hair may be found in long-standing cases, where much of the hair loss is irreversible. questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with a lesion over his right arm. Examination revealed a non-tender plaque surrounded by keloidal scar tissue on his right upper arm. It was located at the site of a scar from a previous injury. Skin biopsy with H and E stain showed lymphocytes, macrophages, giant cells and fungal colonies. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keloidal blastomycosis The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Keloidal blastomycosis (Lobomycosis) This is a rare chronic granulomatous fungal infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. Causative organism: Lac azia loboi Characteristics: Keloidal skin lesions that remain fairly well localized and do not affect the general health of the patient. Site: Anywhere on the body, but usually on exposed parts – the legs, arms and face. associated with injuries to the skin , and spread from one site to another is thought to be by autoinoculation following injury. There is no marked lymphangitis and no visceral dissemination . Old chronic lesions present as elevated, crusted, fungoid plaques. Microscopic examination of biopsy material will establish the diagnosis. The fungus has not been isolated in culture, and mycological confirmation depends on the recognition of the characteristic cells of loboi in tissue in KOH mounts of epidermal crusts or sections, which need not be specially stained. Treatment : There is no effective medical therapy for lobomycosis and where possible lesions are excised surgically .
